_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Chapter 296-67 WAC Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Alternative Case Release Scenario for anhydrous ammonia involves the presumed failure of a transfer hose during the loading of a truck cargo tank.  The scenario assumes that when the transfer hose fails, the excess flow valve on the stationary railroad tank car temporarily freezes open, resulting in the loss of 2,000 pounds of liquid anhydrous ammonia.  The Alternative Case Release Scenario for Trimethylamine involved the presumed failure of a transfer hose during the transloading of Trimethylamine from a rail car to a tank truck.  The scenario assumes that when the transfer hose fails, and the excess flow valve on the Transloader temporarily freezes open, resulting in the loss of 2,000 pounds of Trimethylamine.  

Accidental Release Prevention and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Program:

Multistar Industries, Inc. has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements required by 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA.  In addition, our facility is subject to the WISHA Process Safety Management Standard Chapter 296-67 WAC.  Our facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 reporting requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the accidental release prevention program that is in place at our facility.

Process Safety Information:

Multistar Industries, Inc. currently maintains a detailed record of written process safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment design information associated with our Ammonia Storage and Repack System and TMA Transfer System.
      
Process Hazard Analysis:

The methodology used to complete our Process Hazard Analyses is the What-If Checklist.  The Process Hazard Analyses are completed by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are re-validated at an interval of at least every 5 years.  Any corrective actions noted from the hazard analyses are completed in a timely manner.

Op

d as a regular practice at Multistar Industries, Inc.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that equipment is designed and installed properly, and that operating and maintenance procedures and training are all complete prior to starting up new or modified Ammonia Storage and Repack and TMA Transfer System equipment.

Compliance Audits:

Multistar Industries Inc. conducts audits of the Ammonia Storage and Repack System and TMA Transfer System on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions required by the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Planning regulations are being implemented.  These audits are completed at least every 3 years and any corrective actions noted during the audits are completed in a timely manner.

Incident Investigation:

Multistar Industries, Inc. promptly investigated all accidents and incidents that could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of Anhydrous Ammonia or Trimethylamine.  Investigations are completed as soon as possible after an accident or incident to identify  surface and root causes.  All reports generated by the accident/incident investigations are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation:

Multistar Industries, Inc. believes that process safety management and risk management planning compliance requires a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their concerns and recommendations regarding improving the safety and security of the Ammonia Storage and Repack and TMA Transfer System equipment.  All employees have access to all information required by the WISHA Process Safety Management and EPA Risk Management Planning regulations.

Contractors:

Occasionally, Multistar Industries, Inc. retains contractors to design, construct, inspect, test, or maintain the Ammonia Storage and Repack System and the TMA Transfer System.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of their training, certifications, licenses, insurance and experience is completed.

Executive Summary:

Stationary Source and the Regulated substances Handled:

Multistar Industries, Inc. operates a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution facility.  Multistar Industries, Inc. also transfers Trimethylamine (TMA) from rail cars to cargo tank trailers for delivery to an off-site consignee.   Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3) and Trimethylamine (TMA) are the only Process Safety Management and Risk Management Planning regulated substances present at the Multistar Industries, Inc. Othello, Washington facility.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

Multistar Industries, Inc. is committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  Our comprehensive accidental release prevention program covers the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the Anhydrous Ammonia.  It is our policy to implement appropriate control measures to prevent possible releases of anhydrous ammonia and Trimethylamine.  Unforeseeable, if such a release does occur, our highly trained personnel are available to mitigate the effects of the incident.  We are also completely coordinated with the Adams County Volunteer Fire Department.

Worst Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Case Release Scenario:

The Worst Case and Alternative Case release scenarios were developed using the methodologies provided in the EPA's RMP Comp and Marplot 5.1.1 software programs.  

The Worst Case Release Scenario for anhydrous ammonia involves the presumed rupture of the largest storage tank, a stationary tank containing 160,000 pounds of liquid anhydrous ammonia, due to a railroad switching accident where an inbound tank car is derailed and punctures the stationary tank.  The Worst Case Release Scenario for Trimethylamine involves the presumed rupture of a rail car containing 156,988 pounds of Trimethylamine due to a railroad switching accident where an inbound tank car is derailed and punctures a Trimethylamine tank car located on the rail siding.

The

erating Procedures:

Multistar Industries, Inc. maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround.  The information is reviewed and approved at least annually by the Process Safety Management Committee.

Training:

Multistar Industries, Inc. has a training program in place to train employees who are operating and maintaining the storage and distribution equipment associated with the facility.  Refresher training is provided at least every 3 years to all personnel who operate and/or maintain the Ammonia Storage and Repack System and TMA Transfer System.    
 
Mechanical integrity:

Multistar Industries, Inc. conducts documented maintenance inspections and tests on the Ammonia Storage and Repack System and TMA Transfer System to insure safe operation.  Process equipment examined by these inspections and tests include pressure vessels storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance procedures are performed by qualified personnel with the proper training and experience.  Any equipment deficiencies identified during maintenance inspections and tests are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change:

Written Management of Change procedures are in place at Multistar Industries, Inc. to manage changes in process chemicals, technology equipment and procedures related to the Ammonia Storage and Repack System and TMA Transfer System.  Equipment operators, maintenance personnel, and all other employees whose job tasks are affected by a change in a process, are promptly made aware of and provided training prior to implementing those changes.

Pre-Start-up Safety Reviews:

Pre-Start-up Safety Reviews related to new processes, and to modifications of existing processes, are conducte

Multistar Industries, Inc. informs all visitors, vendors and contractors of all known and potential hazards regarding the Ammonia Storage and Repack and TMA Transfer System equipment.  Emergency notification, evacuation and accountability procedures are reviewed with all contractors prior to them working on or near the Ammonia Storage and Repack and TMA Transfer System equipment.

5-Year Accident History:

Multistar Industries, Inc. had no reportable accidents during the past 5 years regarding the Ammonia Storage and Repack System and TMA Transfer System.        

Emergency Action Plan:

Multistar Industries Inc. has a written Emergency Action Plan to protect site personnel and the public from accidental releases of Anhydrous Ammonia and Trimethylamine.  The plan includes all of the required components of emergency notification, evacuation and personnel accountability as well as first aid procedures and how the emergency response agencies and public will be notified in the event of an accidental release of Anhydrous Ammonia or Trimethylamine.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Multistar Industries Inc. has implemented all of the corrective actions noted during the development and implementation of the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Plans for the Ammonia Storage and Repack and TMA Transfer Systems.  In the future, we will continue our annual planning and training site visits with Adams County Volunteer Fire Department personnel and maintain our membership in the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee.
